head.title: Houses to Replace Golf Driving Range

hedline.hl1: Houses to Replace Golf Driving Range

abstract.p: Louis Vizioli, owner of golf driving range in Greenburgh, NY, plans to sell property to Garson Development Co for $10.5 million for development of private homes; construction will begin after environmental review process, which could take 14 to 16 months; photo (S)

block.p: A golf driving range that the Town of Greenburgh had wanted two years ago for a new town hall and library will now be developed as private homes.

Through its power of eminent domain, the town had sought to buy the land over the objections in 2002. A petition signed by 5,000 people helped persuaded town officials to look elsewhere. The town subsequently renovated a building at 177 Hillside Avenue for its new Town Hall.
A golf driving range that the Town of Greenburgh had wanted two years ago for a new town hall and library will now be developed as private homes.

Through its power of eminent domain, the town had sought to buy the land over the objections in 2002. A petition signed by 5,000 people helped persuaded town officials to look elsewhere. The town subsequently renovated a building at 177 Hillside Avenue for its new Town Hall.
The family that owns and operates the Westchester Golf Range has contracted to sell the property to the Garson Development Company, based in Bedford.
''I think the time is right for housing, and the price is right,'' said Louis Vizioli, 73, who owns the range with his wife, his sister and his brother-in-law.

The developers plan to use the 32-acre parcel on Dobbs Ferry Road to build 36 houses, said Jeffrey Garson, one of the company's owners. Prices for the three-bedroom homes will start at $1.5 million, he said. Construction will begin after a required environmental review process, which Mr. Garson estimates will take 14 to 16 months.
The town had originally sought to buy the property for about $7 million, said Paul Feiner, the town supervisor. The developers have arranged to buy it for $10.5 million, Mr. Garson said.
